replies.author: @JohnMickler-w2t
replies.text: @yellothekunt6826 Framing extreme violence as a simple failure of personal restraint ignores the real structural and gendered conditions that shape behavior. Feminist analysis distinguishes between holding individuals accountable and examining how isolation, entitlement, socialization around masculinity, and unmet emotional labor expectations are produced by patriarchal systems. Saying 'I was lonely and didn't hurt anyone' erases differences in power, social conditioning, mental health access, and gendered norms that discourage men from seeking help while simultaneously teaching them that grievance entitles them to attention. Accountability is necessary, but so is understanding the social context that makes certain forms of violence disproportionately male.

This is not how states or laws should operate, though. They should treat criminals as human and give everyone a fair trial and it gets very dangerous if they don't. It's not a productive method and the role of the state should be to focus on harm prevention and reduction first

Recognizing a rapists humanity is NOT saying that we should just forgive that man/person and let them back into ordinary society. A rapist did a monstrous crime, is a f*cking asshole, and deserves punishment. Recognising that rapists humanity means to recognize WHY he felt comfortable to do the things he did, recognising the fact that we live in a world that FACILITATED the idea in his head that he could rape a child/another human being, recognizing the patriarchy deeply embedded in the collective consciousness of our society, the media we are exposed to, the graphic pornography that young boys are often exposed to, that leads men into thinking that rape is okay, that consent isnt necessary, that he can do whatever he wants. Recognising the rapists humanity is recognising that the same society that raised him and led him to do that monstrous crime, is the same society that is right now raising young boys, that need i remind you, are YOUNG HUMAN BEINGS, to be exposed to the same ideas and beliefs that he was exposed to, that will eventually lead to them doing the same crime. Calling a rapist a monster, is a convenient way to say "he simply is the way he is" and put him in jail(which yes he deserves) and do nothing else. Recognising his humanity will involve having to reckon with the society that raised him that allowed him to think he could do that, and work on dismantling the very deep rooted systems and beliefs that keep the patriarchy and rape culture running. Calling him a monster and doing nothing about the society that let a human become monstrous is simply continuing the society that encourages SEVERAL OTHER YOUNG BOYS BEING RAISED RIGHT NOW TO CONTINUE TO DO WHAT THAT MAN DID. Thinking that simply calling the rapist a monster and putting him in jail, and doing nothing to prevent very possible future monstrous crimes by others isnt just deserved retribution, it is society enabling these crimes by negligence. And recognising that rapists humanity is not forgiving him of the atrocities he committed, nor saying that we dont punish him at all, its realising that if put under the similar circumstances, childhood, upbringing, patriarchal and rape culture media brainwashing as the rapist's, that you or me might as well have done such a monstrous crime. replies.author: @7773CLA
replies.text:
Its really something, how our brains really DONT want to hate beautiful people, anymore than we might want to toss a high quality sapphire to the trashcan.

It‚Äôs a conceptual issue for the species, frankly. Because deformity and ugliness are unsettling to look at, in a vacuum. And, on the other hand, babies are known to like and respond to beautiful faces. So, not to say this isn‚Äôt a massive issue for all of us to work on‚Äîbut it also, very clearly, goes beyond conditioning.

Like, we don‚Äôt associate negative traits to ‚Äúugly‚Äù because of tropes in media‚Äîwe have tropes in media BECAUSE our brains are already making those associations. 

Again, very sad, and something to work on‚Äîbut we must grapple with the fact that we are animals, and as such we want to stay alive. We evolved to appreciate open, friendly faces that are easy to read and pleasant to look at. If you run into a person with intense facial assymmetry, mottled sallow skin, an eye facing the other way, etc etc‚Äîyour monkey brains is sending a bunch of micro alarms to be wary of disease or unpredictable behavior‚Äîyou will, at the very least, take pause, or feel a jolt of caution and alertness. The opposite is true with beauty, which practically has a gravitational pull and a blurring filter to any bad traits. 

I mean, it‚Äôs interesting. We know that beauty does correlate with health markers and predictors we are driven to select‚Äîbut broadly speaking, beauty is an amoral evolutionary feature meant to encourage reproduction, but also, now there are certain parasites that literally will make a person more beautiful as an adaptation strategy to encourage its spreading.

replies.author: @SirSpenace
replies.text:
55:00 To hammer in this point. I'm white, and I'm trans masc so I look much younger than I am. I got pulled over on the interstate by a trooper up to some sketchy business. He was driving so erratically, I thought he was a drunk until his lights came on. He tried to claim he'd clocked me at near 90 in a 65 when I knew for a fact I hadn't gone over 68 (you know, digital speedometers kind of make it obvious). He was a DOUCHE to me the entire stop, and when I was reading the ticket after he went back to his patrol car, he got on his loud speaker to force me along. Which is illegal (my degree is a Bachelor's lol). 

So I challenged the ticket. Showed up to court, and the prick literally called me out into the hall to try to intimidate me üòÇ Little did he know I'm neurodivergent as hell so when he said, "You should probably just leave, you're not going to win" - my only response was, "Why would I leave? I'm already here???" it wasn't until after I sat back down that my processor kicked in lmao

I couldn't prove my speed because I didn't have a recording, but I was honestly shocked at how much the judge let me say. It was definitely that complexion protection hard at work. I basically said, "I can't prove I didn't go that speed, but I do know how a proper traffic stop is done and he did NONE OF THAT." 

I had to pay the fine, but the trooper had to go get retraining on radar protocol so to me that's a win ü§£ü§£ü§£ In that case, I was happy to pay the state $120 to retrain his ass. He needed it üíÄ

replies.author: @SirSpenace
replies.text:
@Neku628 That begs a more nuance conversation, to me. If the person says "I was born evil/a monster/a failure/etc." in earnest, then I think it's important to tease that out and figure out what they were conditioned to think of themselves as from infancy. No one who was ever taught they're worthless ever found true meaning in another person; that's the first step to the sort of dehumanization that's necessary for excessive acts of aggression/violence towards others.

Added note: That isn't to say the crime is justifiable, heinous acts rarely are. I just don't think we can chalk that sort of self-deprecation up to "it's just society or their personal choices." People who can't even grant an infant innocence are going to have a REALLY difficult time forming any sort of empathy. Which could itself be neurological. Brains are messy lol

replies.author: @SirSpenace
replies.text:
‚Äã@kerrissedai6857 No. Not even close. We need to get better *PROTECTIONS* for our DNA. For several reasons:
1. Cops already can't be trusted to share accurate data with us about murders/SAs - there is no way they can be trusted with a huge trove of sensitive information like people's literal DNA profiles.
2. The entire (supposed) point of prison is to rehabilitate. Keeping things like DNA on file is just another way to say "We know this system doesn't work."
3. People are wrongfully arrested AND convicted all. the. time, *especially* Black people and other PoC. Any sort of "DNA Database" that law enforcement collects will be reflective of that racism, not the reality of who actually commits those crimes.

Honestly, I could probably go on, but I think I've made the point. No survivor was ever "helped" through a blanket decision to violate people's rights. 

Passing legislation like that is like using a fishing net to try and catch a marlin. It's not the right tool, and all you're going to end up doing is catching a bunch of BS you didn't intend to.

replies.text:
@S@SirSpenacedidn‚Äôt have a childhood of violence but one of neglect and mental abuse. Like gaslighting in the non trendy internet way but in the ‚Äúno matter what you say or do I will find a way to make you the bad guy,‚Äù narcissistic parent way. And my father literally barely spoke to me and solitary confinement was my ‚Äúpunishment,‚Äù along with other crazy manipulative stuff that has fried my brain in many ways. I was one of those angry kids that was mean because I was so depressed and I felt trapped. I think the thing that helped me was having adults that believed me and even stood up for me. It made me feel less invisible and feel ‚Äúsafer‚Äù to connect to my emotions and trust my discomfort. I found out later that I am autistic so that was a MAJOR part of my confusion and depression. It also helped me understand that I was also being bullied, by my peers and my father, for behaviors I could not control as well. I was not violent but I can imagine that if I had my childhood experiences, my continued lack of understanding from not being diagnosed, and physical abuse; that someone with my temperament could end up being a violent criminal. 

This by no means justifies it because I know I reached a point where I personally was tired of being angry all the time. So there always is some level of personal choice. However, I am a person who was born with a brain difference that never got the help I needed. And was dealing with a father that would literally would be in solitary confinement for entire weekends with him and his wife repeating, ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôd lie, you‚Äôll steal, and if you‚Äôd steal, you‚Äôll kill,‚Äù when I was getting in trouble for literally nothing. So I can imagine someone in my situation + violence seeing themselves becoming a violent criminal that just said ‚Äúfuck it,‚Äù and gave into their impulses but truly being confused and wanting answers.

@SirSpenace That‚Äôs cool but you‚Äôre not understanding another perspective. He had that option because he was not dealing with the people also causing him pain aspect in the way that I mentioned. As I said both my peers and my father were bullying me. I‚Äôm not talking taking my pencils and tripping me in the hall. I am autistic so there are traits that I display that are not ‚Äúnormal‚Äù to most people and they will treat me like shit for it. I legitimately hated people because they had a tendency to hurt me for no reason. It wasn‚Äôt until I got my diagnosis and the tools I needed to understand how to navigate life that I was able to finally break out of that.

A lot of people who end up becoming the worst come from my camp of having a brain difference that needed some extra supports. Specifically if is an autistic person with my specific profile where it impacts you emotionally (it‚Äôs called alexithymia). We already have a hard time connecting to our emotions and internal body cues and that‚Äôs not even touching the other issues we deal with like the world being too loud at time. Then you add trauma that adds even more confusion to the mix. We‚Äôre also very ritualistic, regimented, and as I mentioned struggle with social cues. So that‚Äôs the perfect storm of confusion, loneliness/ hurt, and lack of support. That‚Äôs why I said I could see someone in my situation plus violence becoming a violent criminal.

replies.author: @kaymitchell6143
replies.text:
@SirSpenaceI misread your reply as offering destroying property as a ‚Äúbetter‚Äù option than violent crime. And I think I‚Äôm coming off wrong. So let me clarify. 

This is not a morality check nor am I saying that you were insinuating saying that people should remove all nuance. I was simply pushing back on your opinion by pointing out that your brother‚Äôs path may have been an option for him because he did not have other factors that cause others to choose a different path. 

I also know that you‚Äôre talking about serial killers specifically but I don‚Äôt think they‚Äôre specifically ‚Äúworse‚Äù when compared to other violent criminals. In fact many of these serial killers perpetrated other violent crimes prior to killing. Which is why I wanted to push  back a little bit. Most of the people who commit violent crimes have extenuating circumstances and issues that may have required more systematic support that they never received.

This was meant to be a challenge to your opinion (not a question of your moral standing) because a lot of violent criminals do not even have the tools to self assess in the way Jeffery did. The part I‚Äôm assuming your brother was missing is that part. About 40% of all people in state prisons have a learning, cognitive, and developmental disabilities. And as someone who is a part of that disability list I was simply sharing that there‚Äôs a part of my decision making that intimately tied to the ableism I dealt with. Ableism without an explanation of why you‚Äôre experiencing makes you feel like something is fundamentally wrong with you and can make you feel like you‚Äôre destined to be fucked up anyway. Finding out why my brain wasn‚Äôt ‚Äúworking right‚Äù gave me the tools to understand and process my emotions. People with ADHD may learn tips to help with impulse control. Or I think about my best friend who literally had done some interesting/ impulsive shit she couldn‚Äôt control nor take back before she knew she needed to take mood stabilizers.

I‚Äôm simply proposing that looking at the worst of us, and adjusting resources to prevent others in similar circumstances from going down that path, may be the most comprehensive option.

@true_node that's... that's objectively, statistically not true, unless all of our crime statistics are fundamentally flawed (which... they probably are lol, but I don't see any evidence they're tragically flawed in that regard). 

In the United Stated, DV is about 10% of murders, from what I can find. I would wager in reality it's probably a little higher than that, maybe even 20%. Regardless, there is literally no reality where that number constitutes "most murders". Domestic violence is a huge problem, but lying about/misrepresenting the statistics does nothing but hurt the cause. It gives ammo to those who seek to discredit feminist talking points.

replies.author: @SirSpenace
replies.text:
@idontwantahandlethough That's a fair critique. I should have been more clear, and not tried to speak in vague terms that imply I know some secret to "the meaning of life" or whatever.

When I say people don't "find true meaning in other people" what I mean is that we can't measure our self worth by the actions, feelings, or even existence of any other person. 

I've watched three different mothers in my family lose adult children. So I'm even talking about parents when I say that. There comes a point in life where we all need to realize/accept that we as individuals can only control so much. And, in what little we control, we can "do everything right" and still wind up at a funeral for someone too close, too soon. 

I understand that you personally might feel a certain way about a partner/spouse, child, friend, parent, or whomever. I don't doubt you whatsoever, but being willing to die for someone is a whole different ask than wanting to live for them even after their loss. It's morbid, but imagine a life without them - would they want you to experience any sort of decline for their passing? That's what I mean when I say "no one who was told they were worthless ever found true meaning in another person." If they take that "meaning" with them when they go, what value do you hold in it anymore, y'know?

replies.author: @SirSpenace
replies.text:
@thecia9498 I spent four years learning things like Interrogation tactics, police protocol and procedure, studying case law, and doing lab work to gain the opinions I have on why cops do what they do. You're welcome to disagree, but I think you're still giving them too much credit.

Especially these days, cops realize that media storms are more of a hindrance than they will ever be a help. Now we only hear about serial killers after they're caught. By then, they've usually have "linked" a number of cases to them, many of which are later proven untrue.

The phenomenon you're referring to where cops don't believe people is just called Picking Your Targets Well. Cops are known to not respond to certain calls/to certain people well. TV paints cops as always wanting to "catch the bad guy," when that couldn't be further from the truth. The last thing most ever want is to be called to the scene of a body. Even if there's no suspicion of a crime, you're still strapped with shit tons of paperwork and then have to go tell next of kin that someone is gone. It's not glamorous or rewarding, in any way. Add on top of that that most serial killers know to target sex workers or Black women because they're often blamed for their own assaults, and it's amazing we know about any of them.

And it's not like we have long-running TV shows like Unsolved Mysteries, To Catch a Predator, or America's Most Wanted on TV to keep us in the loop, either. Now we're lucky to hear about it at all lol 

So anyway when are they going to charge the kid that shot Kirk?

replies.author: @TheAwesomes2104
replies.text:
Yes, I've been saying this for years upon years. People compare serial killers to non-human animals or monsters when what makes their actions so atrocious is that they AREN'T non-human animals or monsters (creatures with built in excuses for brutality). Other animals and monsters have very little control over how they live and what they can do, acting mostly on instinct, in response to outside stimuli, and/or as means of survival. Only humans are uniquely capable of evil (which I would define as having the ability not to harm others, but choosing to do so anyway). Evil requires intention, be it the intent to harm directly, for the sake of causing harm, or the intent to do something you know will cause others harm, but simply not caring that they're harmed.

However, given that definition, the vast majority of humans are evil. Nobody wants to look inward. If the average person thinks we're speaking in reference to pedophiles, they'll vehemently agree that it is fundamentally wrong and even evil to ruin anybody's life just to use their body, and may even agree to extreme punishment such as the death penalty, castration, or life-imprisonment for those that act on those desires. Yet, the same person would vehemently disagree with the same exact statement and sentiment if it was about meat-eaters, and insist they be allowed to continue their harmful behaviour without interference.

 Just as the pedo views a child as inferior and expendable, they view non-human animals as inferior and expendable, both operating off the same supremacist ideology of "I am the most important being in the universe, thus anyone I can't see myself in is inferior and unimportant." Sadly, most people will their whole lives rejecting the idea that they could ever have anything in common with those they've deemed to be monsters, despite the basic fundamentals of why they operate as they do being largely the same. It's likely people will lash out at me even bringing it up here. (Somewhat humorously, I often find people both insisting that humans are inherently more valuable than non-human animals, while labelling any humans they don't like as monsters or wild animals. It's the circular logic of "Humans are worthy of compassion, thus if I see a human as unworthy of compassion, that means they're not human.)

It's much like the people in America today who are openly supporting a fascist regime, but truly believe they have nothing in common with Nazis. They've been (understandably) taught that Nazis are monsters, thus believe "normal people" like them could never have anything in common with them. They've lived their whole lives believing it can't happen here because, in their opinion, they're not monsters.

replies.author: @JohnMickler-w2t
replies.text: @yellothekunt6826 The case of Jeffrey Dahmer is often cited as evidence of systemic bias, but the way it is discussed increasingly distorts moral responsibility. Yes, police failure played a role, and yes, racism and homophobia meant that the lives of his victims were taken less seriously. That institutional neglect is real and indefensible. But acknowledging those failures should not slide into reframing Dahmer himself as ‚Äúintelligent,‚Äù misunderstood, or primarily a product of social conditions. He was not uncaught because of brilliance; he was uncaught because he murdered people society already treated as disposable. The focus must remain on the murderer and the crime, not on rehabilitating his image through pseudo-intellectualization. When critique of institutions turns into softening the moral clarity of mass murder, it ceases to be justice-oriented and becomes morally confused. Holding systems accountable should sharpen our condemnation of killers, not blur it.

replies.author: @vixxcelacea2778
replies.text:
@nooneofnote8453 I heard of a guy who complained about head aches and eventually it was found out that he had a tumor in an area of his brain that was increasing aggression and lead to the unfortunate event of him getting a gun and planning to kill someone and then himself.

The brain is a physical construct that can and does mess up. Society should be aware of this and not think that cruelty and horrific acts come from nothing. There is a cause and our best course of action is quarantine the individual until we can assess what the cause is. 
Retribution and this twisted justice model doesn't help anyone. It just satisfies ego to torture those who hurt others. Especially in cases where the cause isn't always clear cut choice.

But that opens up a can of worms about autonomy and personal free-will that people do not want questioned. Easier to say someone is a monster and chose to be one in every single case.

And I'm not saying that if someone isn't at fault that everything shouldn't be done to protect others. I can't stand that limp accusation to even come to the conclusion of. Viruses don't intent to kill. They're just programs who replicate and their replication comes at the cost of health. We don't lock that in a cell and want to watch its public execution. We simply deal with the issue. Either by removing it and studying it and in best case scenario, converting it to be symbiotic or finding another use. Or we eradicate it. In both scenarios, you still eliminate it's ability to cause harm as best you can. Unstable dangerous individuals are the same thing. It's more important to prevent victims in the first place than to feel vindication or sadism when terrible people have terrible things happen to them.
We have backwards priorities when it comes to this.

author: @FlutterBye-gk5ec
text:
When I was in high school (which was also a boarding school), I was being horribly bullied, atop a lot of other stuff which was going wrong in my life. This was obviously very very bad for my mental health, and I started having very violent fantasies towards not only the people bullying me, but the larger school environment. It wasn‚Äôt just about getting a few punches in. I had plans. It felt very, very active- not the throwaway thoughts we all have. 

Looking back, it is horrifying for me, and I am terrified of who that person was, but at the time, it felt normal and rational as a reaction. Nearly ten years on, I‚Äôm still terrified of what I could have done if one or two things had gone even a little differently.

There‚Äôs no need to have sympathy for serial killers, or anyone who commits horrific acts. But I do have sympathy for the child they were before, and the lack of help that was given before things were too late. 

I believe a lot of serial killings can be prevented, just as mass shootings and school shootings can be prevented. But for that to happen, a lot of our social systems, support systems, need to be improved.

replies.author: @kaymitchell6143
replies.text:
Man same! That‚Äôs what I was just trying to explain to someone in the comments. I was an undiagnosed autistic child that was being abused and bullied by my father and experiencing bullying by my peers. I was angry, I was confused, I hated people, and I wanted to die. So had anything gotten any worse I could see that child heading towards a different pathway. After getting my diagnosis I was able to learn so many more skills and learn why people treated me a certain way. I was able to learn what a safe person looks like for me as an autistic person and I was able to finally not be confused and anxious all the time. 

Murder and being a violent criminal is not right. However, we can also take steps to understand how someone go there. And a child who has to fucked up headspace like the one I had might take those steps

text: I remember how defensively people reacted when I tried to articulate this as a teen in school. It pissed me off to no end how people would dehumanize others and themselves on the same breath. The moment you think yourself better than others, above it all, you are letting yourself fall into delusions. What dehumanizes me dehumanizes you. There are no born monsters, we create them in the things we allow, the things we look away from and refuse to confront, everything we wash our hands from. The day we start taking collective accountability for how we have allowed continued horrors to happen for the sake of our own convenience, social standing or personal safety, we might be able to move into healing and fixing our society.

replies.author: @SomeThingOrMaybeAnother
replies.text:
It's not strictly speaking a diagnosis, but... Also, not a legal construct. I don't think there is a "serial killer" crime. It's just x number of murders.
The definition is somewhere around "internally driven" and loosely connected victims, so not a mercenary for hire(with some exceptions) or like a coherent revenge plot. And also has to include cooldown period, so not mass or spree killer. So there is definitely some underlying psychiatric disorder, but not a specific one in all cases. A healthy person would not repeatedly kill to scratch "an itch".

replies.author: @ChristopherSadlowski
replies.text: I'm going to somewhat disagree. I think the term "serial killer" is more a social construct to quickly tell someone what kind of murders happened. Instead of saying something like "multiple murders", which glosses over some finer details in certain cases that "serial killer" more easily captures. So the concept of "serial killer" is a kind of construct, but it's not "just a legal". Like all human constructs, it's what we do with it that can be helpful or harmful. It's a shame that too many people choose the harmful option WAY too much.

replies.author: @dinosaysrawr
replies.text: It also kills curiosity, because the *real* meat is in how and why people become serial killers or don't, and the qualities and autobiographical notes that serial killers tend to share in common. @JohnMickler-w2t
replies.text:
@yellothekunt6826 From a Black feminist perspective, this argument fundamentally misunderstands both accountability and structural critique, while reproducing the very logics that have historically harmed Black communities, especially Black women.

First, Black feminism does not deny crime or excuse violence. Black women have been among the loudest critics of gang violence, misogyny, and hypermasculine posturing because they are disproportionately harmed by it, as victims of domestic violence, sexual coercion, community instability, and the emotional labor of holding families together when men are incarcerated or killed. To claim that opposing dehumanization equals defending criminals is a false equivalence.

Second, rejecting dehumanization is not about sympathy for ‚Äúmurderers‚Äù; it is about resisting a system that has always used dehumanization to justify collective punishment of Black people. Historically, the language of criminality has never stayed neatly confined to those who commit crimes. It expands, first to ‚Äúcriminals,‚Äù then to ‚Äúsuspects,‚Äù then to entire neighborhoods, then to Blackness itself. Black feminism understands this because Black women have lived it: respectability has never protected us from violence or neglect.

Third, the glorification of ‚Äúgangsta culture‚Äù is not a progressive invention, it is a market-driven caricature of Black masculinity produced and consumed largely by institutions outside the community. Black feminists critique this relentlessly, precisely because it traps Black men in a narrow, violent script while leaving Black women to absorb the fallout. But critique is not the same as erasure. You cannot dismantle destructive masculinities by declaring the people shaped by them ‚Äúweak-minded‚Äù and disposable.

Fourth, Black feminism rejects the idea that recognizing structural forces means denying agency. Agency exists within constraint. Poverty, segregation, surveillance, and racialized policing shape probabilities, not destinies, but pretending those forces don‚Äôt matter is intellectually dishonest and politically convenient for the state. It shifts blame downward while absolving systems that profit from incarceration and social abandonment.

Finally, Black feminism refuses the framing that pits ‚Äúgood‚Äù Black people against ‚Äúbad‚Äù ones as a prerequisite for dignity. That logic has always been used to fracture Black solidarity and silence critique. The point is not that ‚Äúracism is bad only when it‚Äôs toward criminals‚Äù; the point is that humanity is not earned through moral perfection, and once it is treated that way, no one is safe. Especially Black women, who are policed, punished, and dismissed even when they follow every rule.

In short, Black feminism says this:
You can condemn violence without worshiping punishment.
You can demand accountability without endorsing dehumanization.
And you can reject harmful cultural glorification without becoming an ally of the same systems that have never distinguished criminals from the rest of us.

That is not insanity. That is historical awareness.

author: @TwiggyKeely
text:
During the trial of Otto Adolf Eichmann, the "Architect of the Holocaust," the phrase Banality of Evil was coined, pointing out how a regular paper pusher can be guilty of incredible acts of evil and genocide. The movie The Zone of Interest explores this further,  it's about The family of Rudoph H√∂ss, the Commandant of Auchwitz, who lived a normal life of luxury right next door to the concentration camp where millions would be murdered.  
And in my own personal anecdote, I've worked on death row at a maximum security state prison since 2018 and I will tell you that these serial killers in my cell house are the easiest inmates that I deal with on a daily basis. They seem incredibly normal,  just average Joes for the most part,  if you didn't know why they were there, you would likely never guess that they murdered multiple people.   That's the terrifying part.
Yes,  it ruins the  "romanticization of serial killers" that a lot of true crime lovers tend to be guilty of,  but that's what's so scary.  You never know if the normal guy next door has bodies in his basement. Ignoring this normalcy is how so many get away with it. They aren't the boogeyman.

Well... I think the implication of a sentiment like that is that they're trying to highlight ideal character. That those who perpetrate such behavior are behaving in a way that should be unacceptable, not normalized, not idealized. It's shunning that behavior, while attempting to shine a light on better values. replies.author: @JohnMickler-w2t
replies.text:
@Trepanation21 The issue with calling harmful behavior ‚Äúnot real men‚Äù or ‚Äúbad masculinity‚Äù is that it doesn't really address the root cause; it just changes who is considered a man. Instead of looking into why these behaviors happen and are accepted, it simply changes the definition of manhood.

This approach seems like a solution, but it still suggests there is a ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù way to be a man. This idea has been used in the past not to stop harm, but to excuse it. Men who act violently are seen as exceptions, rather than as part of a culture that encourages being dominant and entitled, or that allows silence from others.

It also avoids looking at bigger issues. If abusers are just labeled as ‚Äúnot real men,‚Äù then we don‚Äôt have to think about masculinity itself, only individual problems. This makes it harder to hold people accountable because it treats harmful actions as personal mistakes instead of things supported by culture and society.

Additionally, this way of thinking can backfire. Calling someone ‚Äúnot a real man‚Äù often makes them defensive or angry, and can lead them to adopt even more extreme views of masculinity. It changes criticism into policing identities.

It‚Äôs important to reject harmful behavior. But changing the definition of manhood to exclude those who act badly doesn‚Äôt address the reasons behind the behavior; it just protects the ideal of manhood without deeper understanding.

replies.author: @PorterNetwork
replies.text:
‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã@play-fool That explanation does not seem remotely plausible. First of all, that's not how the data collection works. For instance, Radford university's serial killer database doesn't just look for who has been labeled a serial killer in a respective country. They start with a definition, and they look at how many cases fit that definition. "Serial killer" isn't something people get charged with, they just get charged with multiple murder counts. Even if what you're saying was an actual problem for serial killers, criminologists would already know about it because this is a problem with other types of crimes, especially things like rape, where legal definitions vary a lot. Legal definitions of murder don't tend to vary that much. It's why murder rates are the strongest form of data to work with in the field. If what you were describing was an actual problem with serial killing, and it wasn't being accounted for already, that research would be completely mocked. Moreover, I don't see how a methodology problem can't explain the sheer degree of difference between the US and the rest of the world. According to Radford university's database, as of 2016 there have been 3,204 identified serial killers in the United States. In second place, England had 166 identified serial killers. I do not know of any practice (or lack thereof) in England that would account for that gap just due to documentation.

Edit: I did realize these were absolute measurements and considering differences in population between the United States and England I thought I should also standardize it a bit. So of the identified serial killers in the database as of 2016, they make up roughly 9.9% of the population in the United States, and roughly 3% of the population in England. (Just in case you were going to tell me the US has a bigger population than England so of course there's more...)

author: @parentingplus5125
text:
My parents are both sex offenders. They were convicted when I was 8 years old and my siblings and I were placed back in their care after about two years. 

My siblings and I no longer speak to them for good reasons, but it wasn‚Äôt lack of belief that they could be better than who they were. 

I made a lot of excuses for my parents before cutting them out of my life. It‚Äôs really hard to hold what my parents had done, what they continued to do, and who they were as parents in the same mind.

It‚Äôs been ten years since I spoke to them and I still have trouble dealing with this cognitive hardship. I have kids now and I‚Äôll have extreme moments of empathy for my mother as I have to confront how difficult parenting is. And yet I have to remind myself that a growth in understanding on my side is not the same as my parents growing on their own. 

This is really simplified. I‚Äôm mostly commenting to engage. I will say, by all accounts of those who knew my father, he had a normal childhood given what we count as acceptable. And he still became a very tucked up person who did a lot of harm to a lot of people. Honestly, watching this has given me some perspective on his life. I think I always wanted there to be some kind of tragedy that no one knew about. I never considered that he could have just been a miserable lonely boy who grew into a convoluted world view and a destructive man‚Ä¶.. I‚Äôm still thinking through these thoughts.

I‚Äôm not planning on ever talking to them again and I would die before introducing them to my children‚Äôs lives, but I do hope they get the help they need.

Edit: thank you all üíï I do want to add the reason I shared: because of what my parents have done and who they are, they would very much be considered ‚Äúmonsters.‚Äù I wanted to add a perspective that supports Olay‚Äôs main point: that humans commit these acts. My parents were not at all times the people who said and did the horrible things they did. That, (mixed with incompetence of the legal system in this case too) is why it had gone on for so long. My parents absolutely benefited from a legal system that had no interest in acting until they were forced to. And even after that, there was no interest in ensuring that my siblings and I were safe. My dad spent a whole ass 60 days in prison for the things they did which were caught. He is white and there was very much an aura that these acts were a one time thing. They were not.

It‚Äôs hard to be certain, but it seems more likely that Dahmer preyed on POC men not because he hated them due to personal racism but because they were easier targets societally. Unless we find some hidden journals detailing otherwise, there‚Äôs nothing to suggest that Dahmer was particularly racist or that there‚Äôs anything for his father to deconstruct. It‚Äôs all related more specifically to severe mental illness,internalized homophobia, and societal racism/classism.

replies.author: @matteissler365
replies.text:
@mis3ricordia I get where you‚Äôre coming from but in this specific context trying to apply this framework doesn‚Äôt really help us understand anything about Dahmer himself or his motivations. At best it‚Äôs just fuel for POC to hate him more because it adds the context of racism into his motives, but even then it‚Äôs just a barebones posthumous analysis with no basis in evidence that‚Äôs specific to Dahmer. 

We can agree that every white person likely has some degree of internalized racism, but again, it adds no true depth of understanding to this situation that can help us prevent further atrocity. 

At a base, someone preying on others will always go for easy prey, and if a mentally sick person has the ability to act out their desires with success and minimal accountability due to their proximity to marginalized groups, they‚Äôre going to take advantage of it regardless of race. In this case and in many others today(a big example being Indigenous women), POC just happen to be the easiest prey due to specifically structural racism, not so much personal racism.

Not saying to never consider it for criminal cases, just that there‚Äôs next to no reason to apply it to this case given the very real evidence and analysis we have of Dahmer‚Äôs life.

author: @colonelweird
text:
When you talked about Dahmer's change in prison, I thought of Karla Faye Tucker, whom George W. Bush had killed when he was governor of Texas. I followed that story closely when it was happening. There was a huge outcry over her impending death, and it seemed as if something might be done to stop it. I vividly recall that after months of news coverage, she was killed. The next day there were short news stories confirming the execution. Then the mass media forgot her completely - she vanished from public consciousness overnight. It was yet another confirmation to me of how much our society loves death.

And I had no idea about any of the changes in Dahmer that you recount. Though I lived in Milwaukee when he was committing his crimes, and he had lived less than a mile from where I was living at the time, I was too horrified to want to give him close attention.

Thanks for showing the humanity of people like this. It will do little good in the short term. But eventually we live have to learn better. We deny our own humanity when we deny theirs.

The only issue is that people with personality disorders tend to not believe they need help, so it's impossible for them to be rehabilitated. They can also be great at manipulating therapists, too. It's one of those things that has to be taken case by case.

There was really great short documentary about a diagnosed psychopath & they interviewed him. He was very open with how his mind works & even admitted that he was remembering details about the person interviewing him to use again them, if he needed to. He said it just came naturally to want to manipulate for his own benefit. He also talked about how "love" for him was very different than the average person. He sees people like cars.. they serve a purpose, you might need one, but if it breaks down, you just replace it with a new one. No emotions involved. Fascinating stuff.

The same thing was done with the Nazis involved with the holocaust; people thought "how could humans commit such crimes?" so they were seen as inhuman, labelled monsters.
This is dangerous as it not only overlooks that average people were involved manipulated by hysteria and propaganda, but also means that people think it could not happen again in our society because we are not monsters like that. 
Excellent video, like that you balanced it properly, you're not trying to excuse their behaviour, but merely confirm they are human, and deserve to be treated as human. After all; if we treat people inhumanely - we are no better than the criminals we are supposedly better than.

We must also remember that so many serial killers were not caught because law enforcement dehumanized the victims.
